Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Collaborative Research: Ebola-related Information Obtained by Healthcare Providers: Effects of Formal and Informal Communication Channels and Organizational Structure

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
The spread of Ebola from Africa to the United States has received much attention among the general public and healthcare providers (e.g., nurses). Healthcare providers need a diverse range of information in order to protect themselves and the public. However, they may, or may not, be able to obtain such information from their employers. In critical and time sensitive situations, they may obtain information from other sources to complement employer-provided information. This research aims to study the dynamics on the types of information healthcare providers wanted and obtained and their relationships with organizational network and structural characteristics.

This research is grounded in the literature on social network and organizational structure. It also builds on the principal investigators' previous productive collaboration on the health information wants (HIW) concept, framework, and questionnaire, which emphasizes a bottom-up approach to understanding the types and amount of a broad range of health information wanted by individuals. This study can advance knowledge about social network and organizational structure by examining their effects on healthcare providers in various healthcare organizations in time sensitive situations like the current Ebola crisis. It can also advance the HIW framework by examining its use in the context of healthcare organizations. It bridges together these two previously separated bodies of literature and creates new knowledge about the information healthcare providers wanted and obtained, as well as their relationships with social network and organizational structure. Study findings can help develop informational, educational interventions to effectively and efficiently provide the right types and amount of information healthcare providers in different organizations want in Ebola-like emergencies in the future. The findings may lead to improved health and well-being of healthcare providers and the patients they care for when similar crises occur.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The spread of Ebola from West Africa to the United States in 2015 received much attention among the public and the healthcare professionals (e.g., nurses, public health department employees) alike. Healthcare providers of different types of healthcare organizations (hospitals, state and local health departments), who are professionals likely to be exposed to Ebola and contract it, needed a diverse range of Ebola-related information in order to protect themselves and prevent the spread of disease (e.g., information about proper use of personal protective equipment). Those employees who did not provide direct patient care also needed relevant information in order to effectively and efficiently serve the public in health care crises.

Our study had three specific aims. First, we aimed to understand the types and amount of Ebola-related information healthcare organization employees wanted and obtained from their organizations through formal organizational communication channels, and potential discrepancies between the information wanted and obtained from formal organizational communication channels. Second, we aimed to examine the types and amount of information healthcare providers obtained from their informal, internal and external communication channels. Third, we aimed to investigate the differences between hospitals and public health departments in terms of the information wanted and obtained by their employees.

Our study was approved by the authors’ institution’s Institutional Review Board (IRB) and the IRB equivalent of all participating hospitals and public health departments. We collected data from 9 hospitals and 13 public health departments in Central Texas. Participants responded to the survey either online or on paper at their own organization’s choice. Informed consent was obtained prior to any data collection. We collected data about participants’ demographic characteristics, work experience, their organizations’ characteristics, and Ebola-related information wanted and obtained by them from different communication channels.

We found that both hospital and public health department employees wanted at least “a little” of all seven types of information, and they were able to obtain at least “a little” of all seven types of information from formal within-organization communication channels. However, results suggested that among hospital employees, information wanted was less than information obtained for self-care, but was more than information obtained for the other six types of information (including information about diagnosis, treatment, laboratory tests, complementary and alternative medicine, psychosocial factors, and healthcare providers’ credentials). This pattern is consistent for information obtained overall, obtained from internal formal channels, internal informal channels, external forma channels, and external informal channels. Among public health department employees, results suggested that information wanted was significantly more than information obtained overall, information obtained from all channels for all seven types of information.

This work advances knowledge about information wanted and obtained by healthcare organization employees in two different types organizations (hospitals and public health departments) in time sensitive situations like the Ebola crisis. Our findings help understand the utility of having different communication channels for healthcare organization employees in terms of obtaining information in crises. It also advances our understanding of health information wanted by patients and healthcare providers. Importantly, this research bridges together two previously largely separated bodies of literature (i.e., organizational communication and health information) and creates new knowledge about the information healthcare organization employees wanted and obtained from various channels.

Our findings can help develop informational, educational interventions to effectively and efficiently provide the right types and amount of information healthcare organization employees in different organizations want in Ebola-like emergencies in the future, which may lead to improved health and well-being of healthcare organization employees and the patients they care for, and improved evidence-based management in healthcare organizations when similar crises occur. Our research can also potentially help healthcare organizations, government agencies, and professional associations to better understand how information reached healthcare organization employees through different channels in public health crises, and thus help better design communication methods and actively manage the information spread throughout the networks.

Our research has important implications in future emergencies like Ebola. The spread of this disease among direct patient care providers in Texas caused strong reactions from the management and employees of Texas healthcare organizations of all types. This research collected data about infectious disease spread and similar unanticipated public health threat events that can have severe national and international consequences for the health of the population. Our work is critical given the significance and transient nature of the Ebola crisis and the importance of understanding information dissemination within and beyond healthcare organizations in crises like this.
